chapterTitle: Financial Leverage and Capital Structure Policy

columns.text:
$a)$ The following is the order in which businesses should seek financing are :

$i)$ When a company tries to fund its expansion by utilizing existing profits. It must be assumed that businesses make enough profit to invest in their operations is known as internal financing.

$ii)$ Whenever a company is unable to fund its expansion, it can raise funds by selling bonds to the general public, as this form of capital provides leverage is known as debt financing.

$iii)$ Whenever a company's internal funds are insufficient and it would be unable to raise capital through bonds, this should turn to equity financing, moreover, since the market price of common stock is very volatile, this is a dangerous source of capital, and that is why businesses only use this method to obtain funding if they have no other options is known as equity finance.

$b)$ Firms avoid issuing new equity for the following reasons:

 $i)$ Issuing new equity would dilute the firm's ownership and put additional key business data in the hands of more people. 

$ii)$ Whereas if stock is valued, the owners will not sell it at such a cheap price.

 $iii)$ If somehow the stock is overvalued, investors would become doubtful of the company's performance, as well as the stock price has fallen again.

$c)$ When a company's long-term financial goals are fixed, the static hypothesis applies, the static approach focuses upon that financial distress costs as well as tax avoidance, a pecking theory, and onÂ the other hand, concentrates mostly on short-term financial goals and tactical difficulties to raise funds from outside sources to fund corporate expansion and investments.
